Description: A souvenir flask. On side (a), within a border of studs, St Menas stands to front, his arms outstretched in blessing. Above each arm, separated by the head, is the inscription. His hair is smooth, but was perhaps curly in the archetype: the flask has come from the mould with blurred detail. He wears a short tunic and a long cloak, and possibly has high boots. He is flanked by camels. On side (b) Saint Thekla stands to front, bound, between two bulls looking back at her and two hounds (or a hound and a bear). She has hair to her shoulders and drapery falling to the ground. Orange clay, with a buff surface over large areas.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased. Late Roman, about ad 480-650. Comparanda: Sides (a) and (b): near: Metzger 1981: no. 76, dated sixth to seventh century AD. Side (a): close: Kaufmann 1910: 107, fig. 42, bottom left, from Abu Mena, dated fourth to seventh century AD. Near: Cabrol 1907: col. 1725, fig. 449; Kaufmann 1908: 193, fig. 139:2 and 4, from Abu Mena; Rutschowscaya and Bénazeth 2000: 40, no. 6, dated fifth to sixth century AD. Side (b): close, perhaps from same mould-series: Kaufmann 1908: 68, fig. 46:6, from Abu Mena; Kiss 1989a: no. 4, from Kom el-Dikka, Alexandria, context of AD 480-560. Bibliog: Friedman, Egypt Beyond the Pharaohs (RISD 1989): 227, no. 140.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3412)
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: St Menas
